newsitem.title: USA: ATHLETICS-FYNES RUNS YEAR'S FASTEST WOMEN'S 200 METERS.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-FYNES RUNS YEAR'S FASTEST WOMEN'S 200 METERS.

text.p: Bahamian Olympian Sevatheda Fynes breezed to the fastest women's 200 meters of the year on Friday with a time of 22.60 seconds in a semifinal run at the U.S. collegiate championships.

The Michigan State University student, running in cool, damp conditions, also clocked 11.24 seconds into a headwind in the women's 100-meter semifinals and said she had big plans for both events in Saturday's finals.
"I'm hoping to break 11 (seconds) in the 100 and I'd like to get down to 22.2 (in the 200)," Fynes said. "But I don't know if the weather is that good."
Rain and temperatures in the 60s (about 17 C) plagued the championships at Indiana University, but Fynes said living in Michigan helped condition her.

The 22-year-old, who ran third on the Bahamas' silver medal-winning women's 400-meter relay at the Atlanta Olympics, said she was hoping to represent her country again this summer in the world championships.

American newcomer Joey Woody was equally impressive. The University of Northern Iowa student clocked a personal best of 48.59 seconds to defeat fellow-American Angelo Taylor of Georgia Tech in the men's 400-meter hurdles.
The women 400-meter hurdles also was quick. American Ryan Tolbert of Vanderbilt University won in 54.54 seconds with Andrea Blackett of Rice University and Barbados finishing second in 54.78.
Barbadian Olympian Obadele Thompson battled a big head wind of 3.5 meters per second to win his 100-meter semifinal and become Saturday's favourite.
Another islander, Astia Walker of Jamaica and Louisiana State University, dominated the women's 100-meter hurdles in 12.94 seconds.
